Raskolnikov only realized where he was when he found himself on the next street. He looked around and saw he was near a tavern with steps leading down from the sidewalk. Just then, two drunk men came out, arguing and helping each other as they climbed the steps. Without thinking, Raskolnikov went down the steps. He had never been to a tavern before, but now he felt dizzy and very thirsty. He really wanted a cold beer and thought his weakness was because he hadn't eaten. He sat at a sticky table in a dark, dirty corner, ordered some beer, and quickly drank the first glass. He immediately felt better, and his thoughts became clearer.

"All of this is nonsense," he said hopefully. "There's nothing to worry about! It's just my body acting up. Just a glass of beer and a piece of breadâ€”and suddenly my brain feels stronger, my mind is clearer, and I feel more determined! Wow, this is all so silly!" 

Even though he thought this way, he felt cheerful, as if a heavy weight had been lifted off him. He looked around at the people in the room with a friendly attitude. But even then, he sensed that this happier feeling wasn't quite normal.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov, feeling giddy and tormented by thirst, enters a tavern for the first time, seeking solace in beer to clear his mind.
